channel.title: Targeting a DIV using Javascript
channel.description: Found out it's impossible to target a div like a frame, so I googled & it said i had to use AJAX or Javascript. I don't know what AJAX is, but I'm willing to learn it...later, But let's try javascript first. I googled around and got this. [code=javascript][/code] 'indexInfoDiv' is the div that it's going to load the page into. When I click the link: [code=html4strict]Downloads[/code] It loads the page temporarily, then in under a second it goes to that page, in this case being "downloads.php". I know it has to do with the innerHTML, since whatever I put in between the quotes come outs in the DIV then reloads the page into downloads.php. So I'm wondering how I can fix this up? Or is there something else I can use. If it comes to it, i will use AJAX, but I'm running the website off my own computer, it's just for fun to get to know HTML, CSS, etc. So I wonder if I need something to run AJAX? Thanks in advance.

item.title: Targeting a DIV using Javascript
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

[quote=“Wrauld, post:2, topic:268427”]Wiki source:

Ajax, or AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML), is a group of interrelated web development techniques used to create interactive web applications or rich Internet applications. With Ajax, web applications can retrieve data from the server asynchronously in the background without interfering with the display and behavior of the existing page. The use of Ajax has led to an increase in interactive animation on web pages.[1][2] Data is retrieved using the XMLHttpRequest object or through the use of Remote Scripting in browsers that do not support it. Despite the name, the use of JavaScript and XML is not actually required, nor do the requests need to be asynchronous.[3] The acronym AJAX has thus changed to the term Ajax, which does not represent these specific technologies.[4]

Thats ajax.[/quote][quote=“io9, post:3, topic:268427”]If you wanna go directly to downloads.php, then keep it as is. However, if you want the DIV to load downloads.php then you will need to use AJAX.[/quote]

Yeah that’s what I wanna do, guess AJAX is the only way to go. Thanks for the help :).

Read full topic

item.title: Targeting a DIV using Javascript
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

If you wanna go directly to downloads.php, then keep it as is. However, if you want the DIV to load downloads.php then you will need to use AJAX.

item.title: Targeting a DIV using Javascript
item.dc:creator: @Wrauld Wrauld
item.description:
@Wrauld wrote:

Wiki source:

Ajax, or AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML), is a group of interrelated web development techniques used to create interactive web applications or rich Internet applications. With Ajax, web applications can retrieve data from the server asynchronously in the background without interfering with the display and behavior of the existing page. The use of Ajax has led to an increase in interactive animation on web pages.[1][2] Data is retrieved using the XMLHttpRequest object or through the use of Remote Scripting in browsers that do not support it. Despite the name, the use of JavaScript and XML is not actually required, nor do the requests need to be asynchronous.[3] The acronym AJAX has thus changed to the term Ajax, which does not represent these specific technologies.[4]

Thats ajax.

item.title: Targeting a DIV using Javascript
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

Found out it’s impossible to target a div like a frame, so I googled & it said i had to use AJAX or Javascript. I don’t know what AJAX is, but I’m willing to learn it…later, But let’s try javascript first. I googled around and got this.

<script language="JavaScript"> function changeContent() { document.getElementById('indexInfoDiv').innerHTML=""; } </script>

‘indexInfoDiv’ is the div that it’s going to load the page into.

When I click the link:

<a href="downloads.php" title="Downloads Page" target="_parent" onClick="changeContent()">Downloads</a>

It loads the page temporarily, then in under a second it goes to that page, in this case being “downloads.php”.

I know it has to do with the innerHTML, since whatever I put in between the quotes come outs in the DIV then reloads the page into downloads.php.

So I’m wondering how I can fix this up? Or is there something else I can use. If it comes to it, i will use AJAX, but I’m running the website off my own computer, it’s just for fun to get to know HTML, CSS, etc. So I wonder if I need something to run AJAX? Thanks in advance.

Read full topic
